awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will enable students to attend the Verification Mentoring Workshop (VMW 2015) which will be co-located with the International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV), to be held in San Francisco, July 19-24, 2015. CAV is one of the premier conferences in computer science, dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis methods for hardware and software systems. The purpose of Verification Mentoring Workshop is to provide mentoring and career advice to early-stage graduate students, to attract them to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification. Funded students will benefit greatly from the opportunity to engage in the critical technical, professional, and social exchanges that both conferences foster. 

Computer-aided verification covers a broad range of applications, from ensuring the correctness and safety of computer systems, to improving design and development productivity. The funded students will attend CAV, a top conference where they will learn about current research problems and interact with leaders in the field, and the VMW workshop which will focus on mentoring and career advice specific to early-stage graduate students who aim to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification.

por.por_cntn:
The area of computer-aided verification and formal methods is thriving and growing in computer science, fueled by the needs to develop safe and correct computer and information systems, and to improve designer and development productivity. The International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV) is one of the premier conferences in this area, dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis methods for hardware and software systems. We organized the First Verification Mentoring Workshop (VMW) co-located with CAV conference, held in San Francisco, July 18-25, 2015.

The main goal of the VMW workshop was to provide mentoring and career advice to early-stage graduate and senior undergraduate students, to attract them to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification. The full-day workshop program was organized into four main sessions, with multiple breaks to promote interaction and an open Q&A session at the end. The invited speakers comprised a mix of senior and junior leaders in the field. The talks covered an overview of the field (Formal methods: Past, Present, and Future), research career perspectives (Industry and/or Academia), job search advice (Jobs), and mentoring (Life in Science). More details and talk presentations can be found at the workshop website.

Another highlight of the workshop was that we introduced the CAV Buddy System for the first time. The idea is to pair each VMW student with a more experienced student buddy who is familiar with CAV. We set up the buddies in advance, to help break the ice for a student new to the community. This also led to informal discussions and peer mentoring among smaller groups with a good mix of junior and senior students.

After the full-day VMW workshop, the students attended the CAV conference, where they learned about current research results and important future directions. The conference comprised one full day of in-depth tutorials on emerging topics of interest, followed by four days of technical sessions that included invited keynotes and presentations of papers. The conference also included many social events that provided additional opportunities for interaction with others in the research community. More details for CAV 2015 can be found at the conference website.

We are very grateful to NSF for their generous sponsorship of VMW. This supported the travel of 17 US-based students for attending VMW and CAV 2015. Of these 17 students, 6 are women, and 3 (including 1 woman) are from under-represented minority groups. The travel scholarships covered travel costs (airfare, local transportation), workshop and conference registrations, shared hotel accommodation, and meals. Without a travel scholarship, most of these students would not have been able to attend VMW and CAV.

After the workshop, we invited all travel awardees to send a brief report about their experience at VMW and CAV. We also solicited their feedback on VMW through an anonymous survey. Overall, their feedback was very positive, with many students stating that they benefited greatly from the workshop and the opportunity to attend a top-level conference. (Detailed reports sent by the students and results of the post-workshop survey are available upon request.)
